thread.title: Point Beach football beats Spotswood in 76-second span
thread.title_full: Point Beach football beats Spotswood in 76-second span

title: Point Beach football beats Spotswood in 76-second span
text:
Point Beach football beats Spotswood in 76-second span Greg Tufaro , @GregTufaro 8:04 p.m. EDT October 3, 2015 Buy Photo Point Pleasant Beach's Luke Frauenheim scrambles against Spotswood during a game on Saturday Oct. 3, 2015 in Spotswood. (Photo: Jeff Granit) Buy Photo 1 CONNECT 10 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
A 76-second span bridging the first and second halves proved to be the difference in Saturday’s 17-7 victory over Spotswood, but the Point Pleasant Beach High School football team could point to a stout defense and a simplified offense as reasons for the upset. 
Point Pleasant Beach head coach John Wagner – who said he believed his team entered the contest against the defending Greater Middlesex Conference Blue Division champions as a three-touchdown underdog even though his Shore Conference B Central Division squad won last year’s meeting between the schools 9-6 – received back-breaking touchdowns with a minute left in the second quarter and 16 seconds into the third quarter. 
Connor Kells’ 40-yard interception return for a touchdown on a third-and-25 call from the Spotswood 4 yard line for which Chargers’ head coach Andy Cammarano assumed responsibility gave the Garnett Gulls a 10-0 lead with 60 seconds left in the opening half. 
The pick came after Point Pleasant Beach missed a 34-yard field goal attempt following an 18-play, 51-yard drive on which the Garnett Gulls converted two fourth downs and consumed 11 minutes of the scoreboard clock. 
“I went for a gamble in the second quarter (on the pass that was intercepted), just trying to give my guys a chance to feel like they got something going,” said Cammarano, whose team to that point in the contest had not mustered a single first down. “That gamble didn’t work out, so that’s on me.” 
Point Pleasant Beach’s John Nista recovered a squib kick at the Spotswood 38-yard line to start the second half and Luke Frauenheim broke off a 38-yard touchdown run on the next play from scrimmage to give the Garnett Gulls a 17-0 lead 16 seconds into the third quarter. 
“What happened was we had the pick and that got everybody all excited and then we went in at halftime and we said, they’ve got such a big hole on the middle (of the return team),” Wagner explained of the squib kick. “It was a sideline call. We weren’t sure if we were going to do it. It went and then we happened to bust a play off that, so that juiced us obviously.” 
Frauenheim’s touchdown run came as the Garnett Gulls ran iso to the weak side after running iso to the heavy side earlier in the game. 
He finished with a game-high 114 yards on 22 carries, while three other backs combined for 46 yards on 18 attempts (Jason Bowers, who doubles as an outside linebacker, did not play offense in the second half due to an injury). 
Wagner and his staff made a concerted effort to dumb down the offense for his young team, which features three sophomores and a junior in the backfield. 
“This is a game of adjustments,” Wagner said. “We are so young back there and we have struggled making adjustments. It’s hard. We do a lot of motion and stuff. We did hardly any motion today, just because it confused our kids. I put that on the coaches. We tried to take them to a place where we are not ready yet. We have a great future.” 
Spotswood immediately answered Frauenheim’s touchdown run, scoring on its first series of the second half as Joe Hayford capped a 68-yard, seven-play drive with a three-yard touchdown run, closing the deficit to 17-7 with 8:50 remaining in the third quarter. 
The key play of the march was Hayford’s 45-yard run, the only big play Point Pleasant Beach allowed in the entire game, which starkly contrasted the three big plays the Garnett Gulls allowed in a 21-7 loss to Keyport one week prior. 
“We’ve been killed by the big play all year,” said Wagner, noting that limiting such plays was a point of emphasis, as well as controlling the clock. “We wanted to shorten the game.” 
The Chargers, who entered the contest averaging 32.7 points, ran just 12 offensive plays and mustered just one first down – on the final play of the second quarter – in the opening half. 
Spotswood was outgained 117 to 40 in first-half yards from scrimmage and was outgained 177 to 126 for the game. 
Point Pleasant Beach took a 3-0 lead on Sean Gould’s 38-yard field goal with 2:22 left in the first half. He capped a 51-yard drive on which Frauenheim rushed four times for 28 yards. 
Spotswood’s defense, which lineman Lou Vacca, who recorded five tackles for a loss, anchored, gave the offense opportunities to claw back into the game. Point Pleasant Beach punted four times after the intermission and did not convert a second-half first down until the game’s final play. 
The Chargers, who had poor field position for much of the contest, starting seven possessions on average at their own 25 yard line, hurt themselves with five offensive penalties. 
“We had trouble getting going on offense,” Cammarano said, echoing the sentiments of Wagner regarding Spotswood also needing to simplify its Wing-T offense. 
“We made a lot of mistakes in terms of penalties or personnel. With all the motions we do and stuff, sometimes we mess that up. The credit goes to them because they executed and we didn’t. But when you talk about unforced errors – boy, we owned that category. We’ve got a lot to fix. We’ve got a lot to simplify. We’ve got to keep our heads up.” 
Not built to rally from a 17-point deficit, the run-oriented Chargers, whose calls this season have been 77 percent running plays, completed 6 of 10 passes for 60 yards. 
Quarterback Shawn O’Connor faced a heavy pass rush in the second half, was sacked three times and flagged twice for intentional grounding. 
Both teams are now 2-2. 
Key play: Kells’ 40-yard interception return with a minute left in the first half not only gave the Garnett Gulls a 10-point lead, but it provided a sizable cushion that allowed Point Pleasant Beach to successfully execute a squib kick to start the second half. 
Offensive game ball: Luke Frauenheim rushed for a game-high 114 yards on 22 carries, the most important of which led to his 38-yard touchdown on Point Pleasant Beach’s first play from scrimmage in the second half. 
Defensive game ball: Spotswood lineman Lou Vacca recorded a game-high five tackles behind the line of scrimmage and anchored a defense that did not allow the Garnett Gulls to record a second-half first down until the game’s final play. 
Up next: Point Pleasant Beach hosts Dunellen on Friday, while Spotswood hosts Holmdel on Saturday. 
Point Pleasant Beach (2-2) 3-7-7-0 — 17 
Spotswood (2-2) 0-0-7-0 — 7 
P–Kells 40 interception return (Gould kick) 
P–Frauenheim 38 run (Gould kick) 
S–Hayford 3 run (Szatkowski kick) 
Rushing: P – Frauenheim 22-114, Shea 8-16, Bowers 4-17, Nista 6-13; S – Hayford 13-76, Liu 5-5, O’Connor 5 –minus-15. Passing: P – Shea 2-4-17; S – O’Connor 6-10-60. Receiving: P – Kells 2-17; S – Schneider 2-13, Hayford 1-24, Vincelli 1-6, Madsen 1-14, Hart 1-3. 1 CONNECT 10 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE Read or Share this story: http://mycj.co/1RnC430 TOP VIDEOS
